author: holiman
content:
<@456226577798135808> I think I have finally come around fully to the oil idea (two-stroke). It elegantly solves a lot of problems. Previously, a bumped gas could not be "fixed" from the outside by simply "moar gas", since gas can be restricted internally. However, oil gives us a way to "add moar oil" from the outside, since it's global.

So we'd introduce "oil" into transactions, then we could start adding penalties which effectively cause any trie access to cost e.g `3000`. But `700` from `gas`, and `2300` from oil. For the penalty-case: If the trie access was legit, then we can give back the `2300`. 

I think the oil is an awesome idea. Has anyone written it in a more formal specification, so that it may be EIP:ed ?

author: holiman
content: <@456226577798135808> one thing I didn't realize until today, is that it doesn't open new reentrancy attacks either. So it's not like a malicious contract can suddenly use the global oil for nefarious purposes , where he was earlier restricted due to gas. Since the `gas` allotted to him is still the same, it's just that now there may be added costs in the form of oil too.

author: Deleted User
content: yes, that was one of the reasons to come up with this idea - to preserve both functions of gas, but decouple them a bit more
